Barbara Walters, born on August 25, 1929, in Nyack, New York, is an American broadcast journalist, television personality, and author whose illustrious career spanned more than six decades. Walters began her career in journalism as a copy girl at The New York Daily News and eventually became the first female co-anchor of the American television news magazine "20/20" in 1976.

With a passion for storytelling and a keen eye for detail, Walters became a household name, breaking several barriers in the male-dominated world of broadcast journalism. In 1978, she co-anchored ABC's "Nightline," becoming the first woman to host a late-night news program. Her empathetic interview style and ability to connect with her guests on a personal level set her apart, making her one of the most beloved media figures in America.

Walters' influence in the media industry is undeniable; she pioneered the "Money and the Market" segment in ABC's "Good Morning America," a groundbreaking news segment that has become an essential part of the show's brand. In 2004, she made history as the first woman to co-host all three major evening news programs on American television: ABC's "Nightline," CBS's "The Early Show," and NBC's "Today Show."

Beyond her broadcasting accomplishments, Walters has written several popular books, including "My Two Marias," which won a National Book Award, and "Audition," a memoir about her struggles as a young woman in the entertainment industry.

Throughout her career, Barbara Walters has been recognized and honored with numerous awards, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom, which she received from President Barack Obama in 2016, for her contributions to journalism and the media.

Barbara Walters retired from her broadcasting career in 2011 but continued to stay active in media. She has made guest appearances on shows such as "The View" and "Real Time with Bill Maher." Today, her legacy as a trailblazer and pioneer for women in the media industry remains intact, and her accomplishments continue to inspire future generations of journalists

Barbara Walters was born on August 25, 1929, in Far Rockaway, New York, to a Polish-Jewish family. Growing up, she developed a passion for writing and storytelling, which led her to pursue a career in journalism.

In 1953, Walters joined ABC as a news writer for "ABC World News Tonight" with the iconic news anchor, Frank Reynolds. She later became the first female co-anchor of the network's nightly news broadcast alongside Reynolds and John Cameron Swayze. Her fearless, intelligent, and unpretentious style paved the way for future women in the male-dominated industry of television news.

In 1961, Walters began her career as a television news anchor and reporter, breaking into the male-dominated world with her unique charm and determination. Her charisma and talent soon caught the attention of NBC, and she moved on to host her own groundbreaking newsmagazine show, "Today." The show premiered in 1961 and ran until 1975, catapulting Walters to national fame and becoming an integral part of the daily lives of millions of Americans.

In 1976, Walters hosted "ABC's 20/20," a highly acclaimed investigative journalism show that further solidified her position as a leading figure in television news. For her contribution to broadcast journalism, she received the prestigious Peabody Award in 1984.

In 1993, after more than 20 years on air, Walters bid adieu to "20/20" and made the bold decision to focus on her groundbreaking solo interview show, "The View." Alongside other talented personalities such as Star Jones, Meredith Vieira, and Joy Behar, Walters brought her signature interrogative and conversational style to the show, which ran from 1997 to 2007, captivating audiences with her insightful interviews and candid discussions.
